name: Black Death
transmission: Fleas on rats, respiratory droplets (pneumonic plague)
lessons: Quarantine measures originated
Profound social and economic change

name: Spanish Flu
lessons: Importance of public health messaging
Severe impact on young adults

name: Smallpox
transmission: Respiratory droplets, direct contact with rash/fluids
lessons: Proved the power of global vaccination
First disease officially eradicated by human intervention

name: Plague of Justinian
lessons: Demonstrated the impact of disease on great empires
Highlighting trade routes as vectors for spread

name: Third Cholera Pandemic
lessons: Established the link between contaminated water and disease (John Snow's work)
Pioneered modern epidemiology and public sanitation

name: HIV/AIDS Pandemic
transmission: Bodily fluids (sexual contact, shared needles, mother-to-child)
lessons: Crucial role of sustained global health funding
Impact of social stigma on public health efforts

name: Antonine Plague
lessons: Disease spread by returning military forces
Weakened the Roman Empire

name: Asian Flu
lessons: Importance of rapid vaccine development
Showcased the potential for quick global spread via modern travel

name: Cocoliztli Epidemics
pathogen: Unknown (Possibly *Salmonella enterica* Paratyphi C, or a viral hemorrhagic fever)
mortality_rate: Up to 80% of native Mexican population in some areas
transmission: Likely fecal-oral or vector-borne (e.g., lice/ticks) or a mix
lessons: Devastating impact of Old World diseases on New World populations
Highlighting the role of lack of immunity in mortality

name: Typhus Epidemics (WW1-WW2)
transmission: Body lice feces rubbed into skin or inhaled
lessons: Disease thrives in conditions of war and poverty
Crucial role of hygiene and sanitation in control
